title: Perianal Fistula with 6 O'clock Internal Opening
clinical_history: 58-year-old female with intermittent secretion outflow for 1 year
findings_text: Oblique axial FS T2WI shows an internal opening at 6 o'clock position. Oblique coronal FS T2WI shows fistula and external opening. Fistula tract demonstrated with T2 hyperintensity.

title: Complex Bilateral Fistula with Ischioanal Abscess
clinical_history: 38-year-old male with perianal fistula
findings_text: MRI shows bilateral intersphincteric and left trans-sphincteric fistula. Multiple internal openings at 2, 3, 8, and 12 o'clock positions. Multiple external openings on bilateral buttocks and right perineum. Secondary tract present on sagittal images. Associated abscess in left ischioanal space.

title: Horseshoe Abscess with Levator Ani Involvement
clinical_history: 22-year-old male with perianal fistula and abscess
findings_text: MRI demonstrates internal opening at 6 o'clock position. Horseshoe abscess formation in intersphincter space. Inflammatory involvement of levator ani muscle. Extensive soft tissue edema in subcutaneous space of both buttocks.

title: Suprasphincteric Fistula Crossing Puborectal Muscle
clinical_history: Adult patient with perianal fistula
findings_text: MRI shows two tracts in the ischioanal region. The right sided tract runs over the puborectal muscle. The mucosal opening lies at the level of the linea dentata. Fistula course passes above the sphincter complex, crossing the puborectal muscle before reaching the skin surface. Suprasphincteric classification confirmed.

title: Transsphincteric Fistula Posterior 6 O'clock
clinical_history: Adult patient with perianal fistula
findings_text: MRI demonstrates sphincter defect at 6 o'clock position. Defect clearly visible and more apparent on fat sat images. Full-thickness involvement through internal and external sphincter layers. T2 hyperintense tract.

title: Transsphincteric Fistula Anterior 11 O'clock
clinical_history: Adult patient with perianal fistula
findings_text: MRI shows mucosal opening at 11 o'clock position. Full-thickness penetration of internal and external sphincter layers. T2 hyperintense fistula tract extending to skin surface.

title: Pediatric Crohn's Perianal Fistula with Abscess - Single Long Tract
clinical_history: 14-year-old pediatric patient with Crohn's disease and perianal symptoms
findings_text: MRI demonstrates intersphincteric fistula with total perianal fistula length of 3.8 cm. Single fistula tract with single external opening. Associated perianal abscess with mean volume 3 ml. Fistula length exceeds 3.3 cm threshold associated with abscess formation.

title: Pediatric Crohn's Multiple Fistulas with Abscess
clinical_history: Pediatric patient (median age group 14 years) with Crohn's disease and multiple perianal fistulas
findings_text: MRI shows double intersphincteric fistulas with multiple external openings. Total fistula tract length approximately 4 cm. Associated perianal abscess formation. Multiple fistulous tracts (2 fistulas) significantly associated with abscess development.

title: Pediatric Crohn's Single Short Fistula Without Abscess
clinical_history: Pediatric patient with Crohn's disease and short perianal fistula
findings_text: MRI demonstrates single intersphincteric fistula with total fistula length of 2.8 cm. Single fistula tract without multiple openings. No associated abscess. Patients without abscesses had exclusively single fistulas with shorter tract lengths.

title: Pediatric Crohn's Triple Fistulas with Abscess
clinical_history: Pediatric patient with severe fistulizing Crohn's disease
findings_text: MRI shows triple intersphincteric fistulas with multiple external openings. Complex fistula pattern with three distinct tracts. Associated perianal abscess formation. Represents severe phenotype of pediatric perianal Crohn's disease.

title: High Transsphincteric Fistula with Two Setons
clinical_history: 45-year-old male with re-evaluation of perianal fistula
findings_text: MRI reveals left high transphincteric perianal fistula at 4 o'clock with distal bifurcation, with one end opening onto natal cleft and other onto medial posteroinferior aspect of left buttock. Two drainage setons inserted - one through each cutaneous fistula opening, both passing through internal opening into rectal lumen and extending outside anal verge. Minimal bilateral scrotal hydrocele noted. No perianal abscess demonstrated.

title: Supralevator Abscess from Fish Bone Perforation
clinical_history: 48-year-old Caucasian male with localized hypogastric and left iliac fossa pain, fever, absence of fecal passage, and anal pain for four days
findings_text: MRI revealed 6 x 2 x 3 cm supralevator abscess adjacent to prostatic lateral face and internal obturator muscle. Intersphincteric fistula originated from collection's inferior margin, extending in inferior and posterior direction with length of 2 cm. CT detected 36 x 12 mm perianal abscess with densification of perirectal adipose tissue. Fish bone identified perforating rectum approximately 9 cm from anal margin as traumatic etiology.
treatment_mentioned: Abscess drainage and fish bone removal

title: Transsphincteric Fistula with Supralevator Abscess in Cirrhosis
clinical_history: 65-year-old male with liver cirrhosis and purulent anal discharge
findings_text: MRI shows two small trans-sphincteric fistulous tracts at approximately 9 o'clock position, involving external anal sphincter. Large presacral abscess cavity with gas that communicates with fistula tracts. Abscess extends above levator ani muscle (supralevator location). Large volume of ascites due to liver cirrhosis. Trans-sphincteric fistulas with supralevator extension represent complex anal fistula requiring careful surgical planning.

title: Intersphincteric Fistula - 55yo Male
clinical_history: 55-year-old male with anal pain and perianal discharge
findings_text: MRI reveals thin-walled fistulous tract measuring 26 mm in diameter. Tract demonstrates characteristic intersphincteric anatomy with channel positioned between internal and external anal sphincters. Originates in right perianal region and courses superiorly between sphincter layers. Internal opening at 6 o'clock position. Right-sided intersphincteric perianal fistula confined within sphincter complex without crossing external sphincter.

title: Transsphincteric Fistula - 30yo Male
clinical_history: 30-year-old male with history of perianal fistula and purulent discharge
findings_text: MRI shows fistula with thick hypointense signal and surrounding tissue changes. Edema and smudging of right ischiorectal fat planes. Fistula originates at right perianal cutaneous opening, traverses right ischiorectal fossa, pierces external anal sphincter at 10 o'clock position. Continues through intersphincteric plane as horse-shaped tract terminating at internal anal sphincter at 6 o'clock. Both sphincters involved. Fistulography confirms contrast flow into anal canal and rectum. Transsphincteric type.

title: Grade 4 Transsphincteric Fistula with Abscess - 45yo Female
clinical_history: 45-year-old female with perianal discharge
findings_text: MRI demonstrates transsphincteric fistula at 6 o'clock position piercing both layers of sphincter complex. Tract descends through ischiorectal and ischioanal fossae before reaching perineal skin. Small abscess seen in the tract, making it Grade 4 per St James's University Hospital Classification. Abscess associated with primary transsphincteric fistula.

title: Perianal Fistula with Seton Tube - 30yo Female
clinical_history: 30-year-old female with painful anus and vaginal discharge due to perianal fistula
findings_text: CT imaging demonstrates radiopaque seton tube creating loop passing from anal canal through fistulous tract to skin. Seton tube passed from skin into fistula entering anal canal, pulled through to anal verge and joined to skin end forming loop. Seton in place for drainage of fistulous tract prior to fistulectomy.

title: Intersphincteric Grade I Fistula - 35yo Male
clinical_history: 35-year-old male with chronic perianal discharge
findings_text: MRI shows thin-walled fistulous tract on right perianal side with mild restriction on diffusion-weighted imaging. No associated abscesses, branching, or complications. Internal opening at 7 o'clock. Tract pierces internal sphincter at 6 o'clock then travels posteriorly along intersphincteric plane. Grade I intersphincteric fistula. Pelvic organs unremarkable, no free fluid.

title: Intersphincteric Fistula with Horseshoe Abscess - 45yo Female
clinical_history: 45-year-old female with perianal pain and discharge of pus
findings_text: MRI shows left-sided intersphincteric fistula tract coursing between internal and external anal sphincters with internal opening at 5 o'clock position approximately 5 cm from perianal skin. Intersphincteric perianal horseshoe marginally enhancing cystic lesion measuring 2.5 x 1.5 cm with mild perianal inflammatory changes. Abscess has two anal mucosal openings at 3 and 9 o'clock. Pelvic floor muscles intact. Ischioanal and ischiorectal fossae normal. Grade II left perianal intersphincteric fistula with intersphincteric abscess (Morris-Spencer classification).

title: U-Shaped Intersphincteric Abscess - 30yo Male
clinical_history: 30-year-old male with chronic anal fissure presenting with severe rectal pain, fever and elevated CRP/white cell count
findings_text: MRI reveals large U-shaped fluid collection sitting between internal and external anal sphincters with associated edema in surrounding structures. Swelling in left posterior prostate. Marked distension of bladder indicative of urinary retention. Extrinsic compression of anal lumen. Edema in puborectalis muscle and mesorectal fat involvement. Slightly enlarged lymph nodes. Normal perianal and ischiorectal fat. Infection entered perianal spaces through defect in anal mucosa from chronic fissure.

title: Grade IV Recurrent Transsphincteric Fistula with Large Abscess - 35yo Female
clinical_history: 35-year-old female with left perianal tender red lump near anus, 3 months post-surgical intervention for prior fistula
findings_text: MRI shows left-sided trans-sphincteric fistulous tract penetrating anal canal at 5 o'clock position, 2.5 cm above anal verge. Communicates with large perianal fluid collection at ischioanal and ischiorectal spaces measuring 30 x 55 x 80 mm. Recurrence of known fistula tract and associated perianal collection documented.

title: Transsphincteric perianal fistula - Grade III
clinical_history: 20-year-old female with recurrent perianal pain and discharge
findings_text: Grade III transsphincteric fistula per St. James University Hospital MR classification system. The fistulous tract originates at the 1 o'clock position and measures approximately 4 cm in length, briefly ascending and then curving medially through the external and internal anal sphincters. The tract demonstrates T2-hyperintense fluid signal, consistent with inflammatory fluid within the fistula. The fistula extends into the ischioanal fossa and decompresses at the skin surface. Inflammatory changes present within the left ischioanal fossa. Left-sided perianal involvement.
diagnosis: Grade III transsphincteric fistula

title: Perianal transsphincteric fistulas - Crohn disease with horseshoe
clinical_history: 20-year-old male with Crohn's disease undergoing MRI for therapy response assessment
findings_text: Grade 3 trans-sphincteric per St James's University Hospital classification with complex multiple perianal trans-sphincteric fistulas in horseshoe configuration. Primary fistula at 5-6 o'clock position originates at mid-anus level, tracks inferiorly to open in left perianal cleft with seton sutures present. Secondary fistula at 6 o'clock position just below primary tract extends to right ischial anal fossa with anterior perineal opening; also contains seton sutures. Three transsphincteric tracts (two) plus infralevator involvement (one). Mild T2 hyperintensity throughout indicating inflammatory activity with pronounced enhancement of the tract and granulation tissue filling. Previous complex perirectal tract extension above the levator muscle is significantly improved compared to prior imaging. No collections or abscesses identified currently. Van Assche score 10/22; Modified T-score 11/25.
diagnosis: Complex trans-sphincteric fistulas with horseshoe - Crohn's disease

title: Horseshoe intersphincteric abscess with fistula
clinical_history: 35-year-old female with perianal severe pain and discharge
findings_text: Intersphincteric low type perianal fistula at six o'clock (internal opening) with posterior midline horseshoe abscess formation measuring approximately 55x70 mm in maximum diameters at 11-3 o'clock position and extension to right ischioanal fossa (external opening). Edema and hyperintensity are seen with intersphincteric plane and along the anal sphincters. Findings consistent with horseshoe intersphincteric abscess and fistula. Complex perianal fistula with concurrent horseshoe abscess formation.
diagnosis: Horseshoe intersphincteric abscess with fistula

title: Perianal abscess with intersphincteric fistulas - Crohn disease
clinical_history: 25-year-old male with Crohn disease
findings_text: Left ischiorectal fossa abscess surrounded by inflammatory changes extending superficially into the left buttock subcutaneous fat, measuring approximately 7.1 x 1.3 x 2.8 cm (Vol. ~13.5 ml). Lower anus intersphincteric fistulas arising at 2 and 7 o'clock with Seton sutures within. Communication between abscess and fistula tract at 3 o'clock position consistent with phlegmon formation. Inflammatory involvement of the left levator ani muscle. Anorectal junction and distal rectum appear unremarkable with no suspicious lymphadenopathy.
diagnosis: Ischiorectal fossa abscess with intersphincteric fistulas - Crohn's disease

title: Supralevator perianal abscess with sciatic nerve irritation
clinical_history: 47-year-old male with severe acute pain in right hip and right leg
findings_text: Right ischiorectal fossa abscess with supralevator component. T1-weighted imaging shows hypointense lesion in right perianal region. T2-weighted imaging shows hyperintense signal in right ischiorectal fossa region extending towards greater sciatic foramen and along sciatic nerve with air pockets extending to mid-thigh region. STIR sequences demonstrated hyperintense signals with notable air pockets. Diffusion-weighted imaging showed restriction within abscess cavity. Multiple air pockets identified within and surrounding collection appearing as hypointense foci on both T1 and T2 sequences. Follow-up CT three days after surgical drainage showed significant resolution of infra- and supralevator perianal abscess.
diagnosis: Supralevator perianal abscess with sciatic nerve extension

title: Intersphincteric perianal fistula - Grade 1 active
clinical_history: 60-year-old male with pain, redness, and discharge from the right buttock
findings_text: Grade 1 intersphincteric fistula. A high T1 and T2 signal-intensity curvilinear tract with intense tubular enhancement connects the perineal skin to the anal mucosa. Internal opening opens anteriorly in a 1 o'clock direction. The tract makes a right turn after the anal exit zone, then follows a straight course through the right ischioanal fossa before reaching the skin. No abscess or side branches identified. Intraluminal T1 hyperintensity is probably suggestive of proteinaceous fluid intermixed with hemorrhagic secretions in the setting of active inflammation.
diagnosis: Grade 1 intersphincteric fistula - active

title: Perianal fistula Grade I - left intersphincteric
clinical_history: 45-year-old female with chronic perianal infection
findings_text: Simple intersphincteric fistula within the left inter-sphincteric plane with an entry site in midline in the lower third of the anal canal. On T2-weighted sequences, the fistula appears as a small dot-like structure on axial imaging, indicating a straightforward tract without complex branching or secondary extensions. Unusual finding: the fistula approaching the midline at 12 o'clock which is unusual. The tract demonstrates enhancement on contrast-enhanced images, consistent with inflammatory activity and defining the fistula's extent and associated inflammatory tissue. Grade I classification indicates straightforward anatomy. MRI often does not shows clearly the entry point of the fistula.
diagnosis: Grade I intersphincteric fistula

title: High trans-sphincteric fistula with horseshoe intersphincteric collection
clinical_history: 30-year-old male with purulent drainage from the anus
findings_text: Hyperintense fistulous tract extends in the left ischioanal & ischiorectal fossa for about 7 cm. The tract demonstrates T2 hyperintensity, indicating fluid-filled pathology typical of active fistula disease. The pathway traverses the external anal sphincter opposite 3 O'clock arching over the puborectalis and below the levator ani muscle. A horseshoe-shaped intersphincteric collection measuring 3.0 cm in maximum dimension located posteriorly. No side branch tracts were identified. Diagnostic overlap between suprasphincteric and high transsphincteric classification.
diagnosis: High trans-sphincteric fistula with horseshoe collection

title: Crohn's disease with GI bleeding from perianal fistula - intersphincteric with horseshoe
clinical_history: Patient with Crohn's disease presenting with acute GI bleeding
findings_text: Perianal MRI indicated the presence of type 2 fistula according to the Parks classification system or grade 2 fistula according to the James classification. The inner openings were 10 mm from the anal margin, oriented at 4 and 8 o'clock respectively. MRI revealed intrasphincteric-intersphincteric fistula with horseshoe sinus. Complex perianal fistula with multiple external openings and intricate anatomy involving the sphincteric structures. The horseshoe configuration indicated involvement of deeper anatomical layers with communication between different fistula tracts. Fistula's proximity to rectal vascular plexuses contributed to acute GI bleeding complication following seton placement.
diagnosis: Parks type 2 / James grade 2 intersphincteric fistula with horseshoe - Crohn's

title: Dual perianal fistulas - trans-sphincteric and intersphincteric interconnected
clinical_history: 50-year-old female with history of perianal fistula and purulent discharge
findings_text: Trans-sphincteric fistula: A 53 mm thick-walled enhancing tract originates in the right perianal region and pierces both layers of the internal and external anal sphincters to open into the anal canal at the 7 o'clock position. Intersphincteric fistula: A 41 mm thin-walled enhancing tract begins in the right perianal region and extends upward between the internal and external anal sphincters, opening into the anal canal at the 6 o'clock position. The two fistulas are interconnected with connections documented above and below their respective openings into the anal canal. Both tracts demonstrate enhancement on MRI indicating inflammatory activity and vascularization typical of active fistulization. Right-sided trans-sphincteric and intersphincteric perianal fistulas that relate to each other.
diagnosis: Dual interconnected trans-sphincteric and intersphincteric fistulas

title: Grade III trans-sphincteric fistula 9cm length
clinical_history: 50-year-old male with perianal pain and swelling with discharge of pus and blood
findings_text: Grade III right peri-anal trans-sphincteric fistulous tract with involvement of both anal sphincters. Approximately 9 cm in length with opening located at the 5 o'clock position. Thick-walled appearance on imaging. The fistula ascends upward from its external opening, then curves medially to traverse through and pierce both the external and internal anal sphincters before terminating within the posterior wall of the anal canal. Enhancing inflammatory tissue surrounding the tract indicating T1 gadolinium enhancement patterns typical of active inflammatory disease. Mild local perisphinteric sepsis documented. Inflammatory involvement of the right ischioanal and ischiorectal fossae. Enhancement pattern consistent with active inflammation. Both the levator ani and pelvic floor muscles remain intact, indicating no extension into deeper pelvic structures.
diagnosis: Grade III trans-sphincteric fistula

title: Suprasphincteric fistula Grade V with levator penetration
clinical_history: 45-year-old male with recurrent perianal pain and yellowish discharge
findings_text: Posterior midline fistulous tract seen at 6 o'clock position and ascending in the intersphincteric plane. The tract penetrates the right levator ani muscle at the 8 o'clock position, establishing this as a Grade V supralevator fistula (above the external sphincter). A small abscess collection is seen at the 7 o'clock position. Grade V supralevator fistula with small abscess, indicating a complex tract that crosses anatomical sphincter boundaries with localized fluid collection.
diagnosis: Grade V suprasphincteric fistula with abscess

title: Complex transsphincteric fistula with horseshoe abscess and supralevator extension
clinical_history: 20-year-old male with perianal discharge resistant to antibiotic therapy
findings_text: Complex perianal fistula originating at 6 o'clock of the anal canal with measured length of approximately 63 mm. The fistula exhibits a horseshoe-shaped abscess within the intersphincteric space. It continues as a horseshoe intersphincteric abscess and is continuous transsphincterically with the left ischiorectal and ischioanal spaces at 5 o'clock and drains at 3 o'clock on the perianal skin. An accessory branch from this fistula extends above the left levator ani muscle, consistent with a supralevator component. This represents the most complicated aspect of the presentation. Parks classification Type IV fistula with additional supralevator involvement - one of the most complex anatomical presentations of anorectal fistulizing disease.
diagnosis: Complex transsphincteric fistula with horseshoe abscess and supralevator extension

title: Crohn's fistula with sacrococcygeal osteomyelitis
clinical_history: 35-year-old male with known Crohn's disease presenting with pelvic pain
findings_text: Supralevator trans-sphincteric fistula at 6 o'clock of the anorectal junction with multiple branches and a seton suture in place. Additional fibrotic tracts identified at 3, 9, and 12 o'clock positions without fluid collections. Primary pathology affects the coccyx with extension to the presacral region. Inflammatory changes extend posteriorly toward the buttock in the midline. Histopathology confirmed chronic osteomyelitis with focally necrotic but largely viable cancellous bone and chronic inflammatory cell infiltration. Inflammatory infiltrates in presacral region. Granulation tissue in subcutaneous aspect of posterior buttock became more prominent than previous study. No fluid collections or abscess formation. Three persistent fibrotic trans-sphincteric tracts without active drainage.
diagnosis: Crohn's disease with supralevator fistula and sacrococcygeal osteomyelitis

title: Recurrent trans-sphincteric fistula with ischioanal phlegmon
clinical_history: 52-year-old male with recurrent perianal fistula, initial abscess four months prior spontaneously drained
findings_text: Left trans-sphincteric fistula with internal opening at the 2 o'clock position of the lower rectum. Approximately 2 x 1.5 x 3 cm nodule in the left ischioanal fossa. T2 hyperintense ovoid focus showing high signal intensity without appreciable fluid component. Uniformly enhancing mass-like lesion on post-gadolinium T1-weighted imaging with no discernable fluid collection. Well-circumscribed appearance with thin hypointense wall. Minimal surrounding spiculation and relatively less tissue edema/stranding. No central purulent fluid component distinguishing from typical abscess. Mild surrounding vascularity on ultrasound with no internal flow. Normal white blood cell count and hemoglobin. No systemic symptoms or pyrexia. Biopsy and surgical excision confirmed inflammatory phlegmon with dense acute inflammatory infiltrate forming microabscess along with degenerated hair follicle.
diagnosis: Trans-sphincteric fistula with inflammatory phlegmon

title: Suprasphincteric anal fistula - Grade 5 with fibrotic cuff
clinical_history: 30-year-old male with perianal discharge, swelling, and pain
findings_text: Long track extending from the skin of right anal margin, ascending in the medial right ischioanal fossa, penetrating the low right levator to enter the fat posterior to the anorectal junction with internal opening at 6 o'clock position. The track penetrates the low levator muscle, classifying it as suprasphincteric per Parks classification. High T2 signal fluid within the lumen of the track, with a cuff of low signal fibrosis. No secondary tracks, abscess, or seton identified. St James University Hospital classification grade 5 (supralevator/translevator extension).
diagnosis: Grade 5 suprasphincteric fistula

title: Ano-vaginal fistula post-hemorrhoid surgery
clinical_history: 30-year-old female with uncontrollable fecal passage through the vagina following two prior hemorrhoid surgeries
findings_text: Large thick walled ano-vaginal fistulous tract communicating the anal canal (about 3.8 cm from the anal verge) and the lower vagina. The fistula measures approximately 1.7 cm in length and 6 mm in width. It's seen filled by fluid signal and signal void air locules - indicating mixed signal intensity with both fluid and air components within the tract. Non-uniform polypoid wall thickening in the anal canal, lower rectum, and posterior vaginal wall. Multiple enlarged peri-rectal lymph nodes were noted, suggesting inflammatory changes. Additional incidental findings included a right corpus luteum cyst and mild pelvic fluid collection.
diagnosis: Ano-vaginal fistula - iatrogenic

title: Grade II intersphincteric fistula with perianal space abscess
clinical_history: Patient with anal pain and discharge
findings_text: Type: Intersphincteric. Grade: II (low-type). Abscess dimensions of 8 x 18 mm located in the right superficial perianal space with hyperenhancing thick walls. The fistula tract measures 45 mm in length, courses superiorly between the internal and external anal sphincters, and opens into the anal canal at 11 o'clock orientation. The tract demonstrates hyperenhancement with thick-walled appearance on contrast-enhanced MRI. Grade II low-type intersphincteric perianal fistula with associated abscess—a relatively straightforward intersphincteric configuration without involvement of the puborectalis muscle.
diagnosis: Grade II intersphincteric fistula with abscess

title: Ulcerative colitis with perianal abscess - rare presentation
clinical_history: Patient with chronic ulcerative colitis developed right-sided perianal abscess
findings_text: Right-sided perianal abscess. MRI demonstrates submucosal fat deposition and a right sided perianal abscess. Evidence of chronic ulcerative colitis including submucosal fat deposition characteristic of the condition. Perianal complications are significantly less common in ulcerative colitis compared to Crohn disease. This patient represents a less typical presentation as perianal abscesses occur more frequently in Crohn disease.
diagnosis: Ulcerative colitis with perianal abscess

title: Complex perineal abscess with anal fistula tract - post hemorrhoid surgery
clinical_history: 55-year-old male with history of hemorrhoid surgery presenting with pain and purulent drainage in perineal region
findings_text: Well-defined thick altered signal track in the midline perineal region measuring approximately 7.0 cm (anteroposterior) x 3.0 cm (transverse) x 1.7 cm (superior-inferior). The lesion involves multiple perineal structures including periurethral region, base of penis, corpora spongiosa, and extends posteriorly into the ischio-anal fossa. Internal opening suspected at 12 o'clock position into anal canal; no external opening visualized. Post-contrast imaging revealed heterogeneous enhancement with nonenhancing internal components, consistent with abscess formation. Slight rightward urethra displacement. Corpora cavernosa indentation. Subtle marrow edema in left inferior pubic ramus suggesting possible early osteitis. The fistula track with suspicious internal anal opening represents complex perianal pathology requiring surgical intervention.
diagnosis: Complex perineal abscess with anal fistula tract

title: Intersphincteric fistula 34mm tract - chronic discharge
clinical_history: 60-year-old with chronic perianal discharge
findings_text: A 34 mm thin-walled tract starts at the right perianal perineal region and courses upwards between internal and external anal sphincters to open into the anal canal at 12 o'clock orientation. Right-sided inter-sphincteric perianal fistula without associated abscess formation, representing a straightforward fistulous tract without complications. No abscess formation is seen.
diagnosis: Intersphincteric fistula without abscess

title: Grade I intersphincteric fistula 38mm thick-walled tract
clinical_history: 40-year-old female with chronic perianal discharge
findings_text: A 38 mm thick-walled tract starts superficially at the left perianal region and courses superiorly between internal and external anal sphincters to open into the anal canal at 3 o'clock orientation. The imaging demonstrates a thick-walled fistulous tract with enhancement patterns consistent with chronic inflammation. The tract terminates within the anal canal at the 3 o'clock position, representing the internal opening location typical of intersphincteric-type fistulas. No abscess formation documented, confirming this as uncomplicated Grade I disease without associated fluid collection. Low-type intersphincteric fistula without complications.
diagnosis: Grade I intersphincteric fistula

title: Complex perianal fistula with mucinous adenocarcinoma - recurrent
clinical_history: 54-year-old male with 10-year history of recurrent anal fistulas, diarrhea, weight loss, fever
findings_text: Complex anal fistula with extensive involvement. MRI demonstrated extensive inflammation and fistula formation in the lower rectal segment and the perianal space, sacral anterior space, bilateral ischiorectal fossa, and gluteus maximus space. T2-weighted imaging revealed perianal abnormal high-signal lesions with multiple separated, well-defined, cystic lesions predominantly seen on the left side of the subcutaneous tissue of the buttocks. T1-weighted sequences showed patchy, iso-signal lesions around the anal region, with some areas exhibiting patchy high signal intensity. Formation of perianal abscess alongside the fistula network. Diagnosis: Perianal mucinous adenocarcinoma confirmed via tissue biopsy. Malignancy must be considered in recurrent fistulas.
diagnosis: Complex fistula with perianal mucinous adenocarcinoma

title: Grade V extrasphincteric fistula presenting as buttock soft tissue mass
clinical_history: Patient with chronic abscess cavity in right buttock enlarging over 2.5 years
findings_text: Extrasphincteric fistula with no rectal communication. Grade V (supralevator and translevator disease). The MRI revealed the fistulous tract in its perianal course was seen on the right side in the extrasphincteric region extending superiorly, traversing the right ischiorectal fossa with a likely breech of the right levator ani plate. Tract length: 7 cm fistulous tract with internal ramifications present. Medially terminated with no obvious rectal communication; the internal opening appeared obliterated over time. A chronic abscess cavity was identified in the subcutaneous region of the right buttock, measuring as a large lesion. Grade V indicated less favorable outcome leading to recurrences needing reoperations.
diagnosis: Grade V extrasphincteric fistula with chronic buttock abscess

title: Complex intersphincteric fistula with multiple ducts and openings
clinical_history: Patient with complex anal fistula
findings_text: Intersphincter anal fistula based on imaging and intraoperative findings. T2 sagittal position screenage displayed that the ducts did not connect with rectum, but the boundary between sphincter and diseased was indistinct. Long T1 signal combined with short T2 signal lesions identified with the region of long T1 signal combined short T2 signal occupied area of 54.2mm x 9.9mm. Partial lesion reach ani internus sphincter. The deeper aspect was not in contact with muscles while superficial portion penetrated the skin. A distinguishing feature was the presence of a number of ducts with different length and orientation, which differed from typical intersphincteric fistulas that usually have single external openings. Intraoperatively three external openings found at 6, 8, and 10 o'clock positions, all connecting to the 6 o'clock internal opening.
diagnosis: Complex intersphincteric fistula with multiple ducts

title: Low anterior anal fistula to scrotum base - post-abscess
clinical_history: 40-year-old male with history of previously drained abscess at the scrotum base, with subsequent fistula formation
findings_text: Fistulous tract from the low anterior anal canal just above the anal verge (well below puborectalis) to the base of the scrotum. Straight T2 weighted imaging is best to define these tracts in all 3 planes for optimal visualization. Skin thickening with enhancement reflecting inflammatory changes in surrounding tissues. No distinct abscess cavity identified. The fistula originates from the low anterior anal canal, positioned just above the anal verge—significantly below the puborectalis muscle level.
diagnosis: Low anterior anal fistula post-abscess

title: Grade 1 simple intersphincteric fistula - prior abscess
clinical_history: 49-year-old male with prior perirectal abscesses
findings_text: Grade 1 simple intersphincteric fistula. T2W fat-suppressed axial and coronal images showing fistula originating from internal sphincter with tract interposed between internal and external sphincter. Fistula exits through perineum between sphincters. No abscess noted.
diagnosis: Grade 1 intersphincteric fistula

title: Grade 2 complex intersphincteric horseshoe fistula - Crohn's
clinical_history: 26-year-old female with Crohn's disease
findings_text: Grade 2 complex intersphincteric fistula with horseshoe pattern. T2W high-resolution axial showing fistulous track in a horseshoe pattern extending from 3:30 to 9:30 clock positions. Tract courses between internal and external sphincters with circumferential distribution.
diagnosis: Grade 2 complex intersphincteric horseshoe fistula - Crohn's disease

title: Grade 2 complex intersphincteric with perianal abscess - Crohn's
clinical_history: 18-year-old male with ileocolonic Crohn's disease
findings_text: Grade 2 complex intersphincteric fistula. Coronal fat-suppressed T2WI demonstrating fistula and associated perianal abscess. Tract shows inferior extent between sphincters. Perianal abscess present hyperintense on T2.
diagnosis: Grade 2 complex intersphincteric fistula with perianal abscess - Crohn's disease

title: Grade 3 simple transphincteric fistula - prior abscess
clinical_history: 49-year-old male with prior perirectal abscess
findings_text: Grade 3 simple transphincteric fistula. Axial T2W fat-saturated image showing simple transphincteric fistula arising from right aspect of superior anal canal violating external sphincter. Tract penetrates both sphincters. No abscess noted.
diagnosis: Grade 3 transphincteric fistula

title: Grade 4 complex transphincteric with rim-enhancing abscess
clinical_history: 25-year-old woman with prior perirectal abscess
findings_text: Grade 4 complex transphincteric fistula. Post-contrast T1W GRE showing rim enhancing abscess with transsphincteric grade 4 fistula penetrating external sphincter on left. Abscess demonstrates rim enhancement with hypointense center.
diagnosis: Grade 4 transphincteric fistula with abscess

title: Grade 5 suprasphincteric with supralevator fluid collections
clinical_history: 45-year-old man with prior perirectal abscess
findings_text: Grade 5 suprasphincteric fistula. T2W fat-suppressed coronal showing hyperintense fluid collection and edema above and below levator plate. Supralevator component identified above levator plate. Fluid collections above and below levator noted.
diagnosis: Grade 5 suprasphincteric fistula with supralevator extension

title: Multiple grade 4 and 5 fistulas bilateral - Crohn's with setons
clinical_history: 26-year-old female with Crohn's disease
findings_text: Multiple fistulae Grade 4 and Grade 5. Coronal 3D TSE and fat-suppressed T2WI demonstrating well-defined fistulous tract and collection in ischioanal fossa with extensive disease with supralevator extension. Bilateral involvement with Grade 4 on right and Grade 5 on left. Collection in ischioanal fossa on right. Abscess beneath levator plate on left. Transphincteric setons visualized bilaterally.
diagnosis: Multiple grade 4 and 5 bilateral fistulas with setons - Crohn's disease

title: Isolated rectal wall abscess without fistula - rare presentation
clinical_history: 34-year-old male with spontaneous rectal pain, WCC 14.3, CRP 93
findings_text: A 25 mm abscess within the posterior wall of the lower rectum positioned 7 cm from the anal verge and far superior to the anal canal. T2-weighted images on MRI (sagittal view) showing the collection. No fistula communication identified. Per rectal examination revealed a firm mass at the 6-7 o'clock position. Follow-up MRI showed no evidence of residual abscess or fistulae in the perianal and rectal areas. Abscess drained via transrectal approach.
diagnosis: Rectal wall abscess without fistula

title: Grade 4 trans-sphincteric fistula with perianal abscess - DWI hyperintense
clinical_history: Adult patient with perianal abscess
findings_text: Grade 4 trans-sphincteric fistula. Right perianal abscess - large heterogeneous collection with internal air foci. DWI hyperintense signal with corresponding signal drop on ADC indicating restricted diffusion. T2 STIR hyperintense signal. Small trans-sphincteric fistula at 11 o'clock position crossing external sphincter.
diagnosis: Grade 4 trans-sphincteric fistula with abscess

title: Grade 4 trans-sphincteric fistula with peripheral enhancement - DWI study
clinical_history: Adult patient with perianal abscess
findings_text: Grade 4 trans-sphincteric fistula. Right perianal abscess - heterogeneously and predominantly peripherally enhancing collection. DWI hyperintense with restricted diffusion on ADC. Demonstrates inflammation showing hyperintense signal on T2 STIR with no restriction on DWI (differentiating abscess from inflammation). Curvilinear trans-sphincteric fistula at 8 o'clock position crossing external sphincter.
diagnosis: Grade 4 trans-sphincteric fistula with peripherally enhancing abscess

title: Grade 2 intersphincteric fistula with small abscess - DWI restriction
clinical_history: Adult patient with perianal abscess
findings_text: Grade 2 intersphincteric fistula. Small abscess near internal opening of intersphincteric fistula with heterogeneous enhancement. DWI hyperintense with signal drop on ADC indicating restricted diffusion. Internal opening at 6 o'clock position.
diagnosis: Grade 2 intersphincteric fistula with small abscess

title: Radiation-induced rectovaginal fistula - elderly female
clinical_history: Elderly woman with pelvic radiotherapy history
findings_text: Rectovaginal fistula. Sagittal T2-weighted MRI image shows a 1-cm wide fistula between the most distal aspect of stool-filled rectum. Midline connection between distal rectum and vagina. High T2-weighted signal in fistula tract.
diagnosis: Radiation-induced rectovaginal fistula

title: Post-surgical rectovaginal fistula with mesh - prolapse repair
clinical_history: Woman with prior bladder/uterine prolapse repair using mesh
findings_text: Rectovaginal fistula. Wide fluid-filled communication between the distal rectum and upper third of the vagina with marked peripheral enhancement. Connects distal rectum to upper vaginal third. Fluid-filled with T2 hyperintensity; marked enhancement post-gadolinium.
diagnosis: Post-surgical rectovaginal fistula

title: Anovaginal fistula from ileal pouch - ulcerative colitis
clinical_history: 44-year-old with ulcerative colitis post-total proctocolectomy
findings_text: Anovaginal fistula. Fluid distension of the ileal pouch and a small midline fistula connecting the IPAA (ileal pouch-anal anastomosis) to the vagina. Midline tract from ileal pouch-anal anastomosis to vagina. Fluid-filled; T2-hyperintense.
diagnosis: Anovaginal fistula from ileal pouch - ulcerative colitis

title: Simple anovaginal fistula - Crohn's disease
clinical_history: 41-year-old with Crohn's disease
findings_text: Anovaginal fistula. Midline fluid-filled track coursing through the anovaginal septum to reach the lower third of the vagina. Midline path crossing anovaginal septum to lower vagina. High T2-weighted signal on sagittal/axial fat-suppressed sequences.
diagnosis: Simple anovaginal fistula - Crohn's disease

title: Anovaginal fistula with seton - Crohn's on infliximab
clinical_history: 36-year-old with colonic Crohn's disease
findings_text: Anovaginal fistula. Thin midline tract on axial FS T1-weighted image after gadolinium CM with positioning of a seton through the ano-VF. Thin midline tract to vagina with therapeutic seton placement. Follow-up imaging post-infliximab therapy.
diagnosis: Anovaginal fistula with seton - Crohn's disease

title: Complex anovaginal fistula with anovaginal septum abscess - refractory Crohn's
clinical_history: 40-year-old with severe, refractory Crohn's disease
findings_text: Rectovaginal fistula with associated abscess. Small-sized abscess of the anovaginal septum originating from a midline recto-VF with strong enhancement on FS T1-weighted image. Midline recto-VF extending to anovaginal septum abscess. Abscess shows high T2 signal with strong peripheral enhancement. Repeated MRI shows widened recto-VF and bilateral levator ani abscesses.
diagnosis: Complex rectovaginal fistula with anovaginal septum abscess - Crohn's disease

title: Anovaginal fistula with levator ani abscess - Crohn's disease
clinical_history: 50-year-old with Crohn's disease
findings_text: Anovaginal fistula with abscess. Fluid-filled abscess cavities with strong mural enhancement. Severe proctitis as circumferential thickening of rectal walls with oedematous submucosa. Abscess extending from anovaginal septum to levator ani muscle. Fluid collections show high T2 signal with homogeneous enhancement.
diagnosis: Anovaginal fistula with levator ani abscess - Crohn's disease

title: Anal tuberculosis presenting as perianal fistula - rare case
clinical_history: 25-year-old male with frequent stools, fecal incontinence, blood in feces, painful defecation and straining since past five months
findings_text: Mural thickening of the rectum and the rectosigmoid junction with significant adjacent fat stranding. Linear tract traversing to rectum piercing the internal mucosa at 6 o'clock position with soft tissue enhancement. Multiple small intercommunicating pockets of collections measuring 8.0 mm x 2.2 mm x 3.2 mm in the pre-sacral region inseparable from the rectosigmoid junction. Sigmoidoscopy revealed severe ulcerations with friable mucosa. Three fistula openings—one 3 cm from anal verge and two just above it. Histopathology showed granulomatous inflammation with caseating necrosis confirming tuberculosis.
diagnosis: Anal tuberculosis presenting as perianal fistula

title: Grade V perianal fistula with horseshoe supralevator extension - recurrent
clinical_history: 50-year-old male with recurrent fistula that had undergone two prior treatment attempts without resolution, significant mobility impairment
findings_text: Right ischioanal abscess with two large tracks extending in the intersphincteric plane in a horseshoe pattern from 2 to 11 o'clock position. Fistulous tracts demonstrate extensive involvement progressing beyond local boundaries to reach the supralevator space and perirectal region. Diffuse accompanying perianal subcutaneous edema indicates inflammatory changes throughout surrounding tissues. Long standing recurrent fistulae result in abscess formation that eventually spreads. The horseshoe configuration with supralevator extension represents advanced complexity reflecting treatment-resistant disease.
diagnosis: Grade V recurrent perianal fistula with horseshoe supralevator extension

title: Complex fistula-in-ano extending from anal canal to mid-thigh 20cm
clinical_history: 60-year-old male with discharging sinus on posteromedial aspect of left thigh for two years
findings_text: Fluid-filled marginally enhancing tract ascending obliquely from the skin of the posterior left thigh, passing through the left gluteus maximus to the bilateral ischioanal fossae. High signal intensity demonstrated in the intersphincteric plane consistent with classic perianal fistula presentation at the 1 o'clock position. Two external openings on posteromedial aspect of the left thigh 20 cm away from the anal verge extending toward the left buttock with an internal opening on the right side of the anal canal at 11 o'clock. Distal 7 cm tract was excised as the rest of the tract was deep passing through the gluteus maximus. VAAFT procedure done for remaining tract. No associated Crohn's disease, malignancy, or tuberculosis identified.
diagnosis: Complex fistula-in-ano extending to mid-thigh

title: Primary complex anal fistula with 7 external openings - 3D MRI guided
clinical_history: 36-year-old male with 10-year history of recurrent pus flow from paranal mass
findings_text: Enhanced MRI revealed 2 canal-like structures with low T1 and high T2 signal, with restricted diffusion and significant enhancement. 3D reconstruction shows: Primary branch at 5 o'clock originates 3 cm from anal opening extending along inner and outer sphincter layers with internal opening at 7 o'clock above anal sphincter. Secondary branch at 2 o'clock divides into two pathways - one penetrates internal sphincter at 2 o'clock dentition, one traverses external sphincter toward anterior. Anterior extension branches into 4 separate tracts from 3-4 o'clock region with three openings extending 3-5 cm laterally. One branch extends anteriorly toward scrotal region dividing into 3 branches at scrotal root. Seven visible masses with purulent drainage on exam. Negative tuberculosis workup. Normal colonoscopy.
diagnosis: Primary complex anal fistula with 7 external openings
